Verilog code typically has a specific structure that can be read and understood, with module declarations, input/output definitions, and gate/logic descriptions. However, the text you've provided doesn't appear to follow that structure.

I suggest providing a readable and valid form of Verilog code so I can assist you with your request properly.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
I regret to inform you that the provided content is not in Verilog RTL code format or any recognizable code format. Unfortunately, it seems like gibberish or corrupted data. Therefore, it is impossible to extract any meaningful information or answer your questions regarding internal signals or any other elements related to Verilog code from the given content. 

For your reference, this is what typical Verilog code looks like:

```verilog
module myModule(input clk, output reg q);
   reg d;
   
   always @(posedge clk) 
   begin
      d <= q;
      q <= d;
   end
endmodule
```

This is a simple Verilog code for a D flip-flop. 'clk' is the clock input, 'q' is the output, and 'd' is an internal signal. On the rising edge of the clock, 'd' takes the value of 'q' and then 'q' takes the value of 'd'. 

Please provide valid Verilog RTL code, and I will be happy to assist you further.
